title: If statements can be fact checked, why do politicians get away with lying or 'stretching the truth'? - Quora
tags: Politics of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Most people don’t bother; don’t have the critical thinking skills to notice or the cognition to recognize a questionable fact. Finding fault with a favored politician is unsatisfying, so why”, bother? How many people listen to politicians whose lies make them uncomfortable? I can’t listen to most Republicans any more because their false facts and misrepresentation of mainstream Democratic positions is aggravating and so dangerous. If they are not outright lying, they are presenting a caricature of the opposition’s position that pretends execution of a policy would require an absurdly extreme action. For example: No Democrat at this point in time wants open borders. But neither do they want forever split up families as a deterrent. They want a reasonable solution that would permit tightening border control without destroying families, ignoring human rights, and ensuring reasonable compassion toward immigrants whose lives are threatened with death, gang terror, or extra-judicial punishment. This is neither as simple as building a wall or allowing an open border, though Republican Presidents have favored both approaches. An effective, realistic solution that would work while consuming an appropriate amount of resources, is complex and impossible to communicate in a slogan or chant like “Build the Wall.” Or a flat out lie, like “Mexico will pay for it.” One won’t solve the problem and the other is untrue but impossible to refute. That’s why fact-checking by Democrats is unconvincing and impractical. Trump and a growing number of Republicans, use weasel words, The Big Lie stated with confidence, oversimplification and or flat out misrepresentation of the Democratic position, to influence voters. Never before do I remember this being practiced so blatantly or frequently as under the Trump Administration. Failure is described as success, the effectiveness of Covid testing is flip-flopped according to political not scientific outcomes, and the White House position on issues is demanded of our scientific institutions normally considered bedrock in making difficult or ambiguous decisions. Nowadays, heads of these agencies, appointed by Trump, are forced to comply or risk their livelihoods and careers. That’s why calling out lies in real time isn’t very effective against Trump’s coup. These tactics also offers a piece of the explanation for how Trump got elected in the first place. The electorate, the press, and frankly the other two branches of government have never had to deal with this level of deceit, cheating, and lies from a Presidential candidate and a major political party.

The question focuses on the bark so misses the forest and the entire bio-system that put it there. It’s interesting that the public at large is not educated, and certainly not by popular media, on a simple fact. Big Media, the 6 corporations that own 90% of the media The 6 Companies That Own (Almost) All Media [INFOGRAPHIC], has become a political tool whose existence depends on serving the political and other biases of their advertisers, stockholders, and other management concerns. There’s nothing like working in this industry to see firsthand how truth in reporting is skewed to fit management’s agenda and the corporation’s public niche. Truth is down the list of concerns, whereby their reality of truth becomes distorted. Why the News Is Not the Truth - Harvard Business Review Pop media would have us believe that Trump all but introduced ‘alternate truth,’ while they all use it prolifically, and which fails to acknowledge that that’s been the level of human reason throughout history. Voltaire called history as recorded by historians, “A Mississippi of lies,” that finally becomes, “The lie that everyone agrees on…” He wasn’t one of the greatest philosophers because he got things wrong. I love the way Kevin Spacey put it in the movie Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil, “Truth, like art, is in the eye of the beholder.” It captures human nature’s tendency toward pleasure. The cold, stark creature of truth isn’t often invited over for dinner, evidenced in the vast popularity of movies over documentaries.

Confirmation bias leads one to discount information that goes against what we already believe, so if the fact check comes up with something contrary to our ideas, we will either not believe the fact checker, say that the false item is not significant or say “all politicians lie.” I have the greatest regard for fact checkers and I do not condone lies, so my confirmation bias errors will be in the second category. Politifact gave Obama the 2013 “Lie of the Year” award for “If you like your health care plan, you can keep it.”[1] Obama said that, and some people couldn’t keep their plans. I go into apologetic mode and say that the Affordable Care Act had a provision to grandfather in existing plans that didn’t meet ACA standards. I’ll blame insurance companies for dropping the old plans that no longer conformed to the law. I’ll say Obama didn’t intentionally lie; things just turned out differently than he expected. I stand behind my apology and I think it’s fair, but I use this anecdote about my own bias to explain how it works, how Obama said something that wasn’t true and I discount it. For some, they will just look at the fact check, wave their magic wands and chant the magic incantation. “liberal media.” and the problem just vanishes. Footnotes[1] PolitiFact - Lie of the Year: 'If you like your health care plan, you can keep it'

We have freedom of speech and unless a person’s remarks can be shown to have caused harm, thus giving the damaged person reason to sue, there is no way to stop them. We have relied on “an informed public” to see us through our democracy. Obviously the system needs refining. In any case, taking Trump as an example, his followers don’t care if he lies. They think it’s leadership. They cheer him when he lies.

Because too many people only want to hear what aligns with their ideology and don’t want to hear facts. In fact, their ideology is to never trust “facts.” Don’t trust the educated, don’t trust science, don’t trust experience. Only trust the reich! Reichwingers will eat any shit their leaders shovel.

I’m not so sure they’re getting away with anything but moving their lips. I feel so many people know already that most are lies, but have decided, in their mind, they are not voting for that person anyway, so why bother fact checking.

Most people don’t pay that much attention. They just pick up superficially on the effect of what someone is saying to see whether the pol is on the right track. It’s amazing. It makes politicians become mendacious scum and makes the political process a system of deceit and contempt for the truth.
Most of the time, the media stays out of it, except for this election. This time, all you have to do is google ‘Trump lies"

Actually, it depends on who is doing the fact checking. They are not always impartial. Also some things said by people are not meant to be taken literally. If you said you laughed your head off and a fact checker said you were lying as your head was still in place would you really be a liar?
A) Because they know most people won’t try to verify what they say just believe it b) they tell “stretch the truth” for the same reason
They are exempt. In one way it is a good thing because all we would be doing is following libel lawsuits and everyone would be afraid to speak.
